io.atomix.resource

Interface Resource<T extends Resource<T>>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - resource type
    All Superinterfaces:
    Managed<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractDistributedValue, AbstractResource, DistributedGroup, DistributedLock, DistributedLong, DistributedMap, DistributedMessageBus, DistributedMultiMap, DistributedQueue, DistributedSet, DistributedTaskQueue, DistributedTopic, DistributedValue

    public interface Resource<T extends Resource<T>>
extends Managed<T>
    Base class for fault-tolerant stateful distributed objects.

    Resources are stateful distributed objects that run across a set of CopycatServers in a cluster.

    Resources can be created either as standalone StateMachines in a typical Copycat cluster or as Atomix resources. Operations on the resource are translated into Commands and Querys which are submitted to the cluster where they're logged and replicated.

    Resource implementations must be annotated with the ResourceTypeInfo annotation to indicate the ResourceStateMachine to be used by the Atomix resource manager. Additionally, resources must be registered via the ServiceLoader pattern in a file at META-INF/services/io.atomix.resource.Resource on the class path. The resource registration allows the Atomix resource manager to locate and load the resource state machine on each server in the cluster.

    Resources have varying consistency guarantees depending on the configured resource WriteConsistency and ReadConsistency and the semantics of the specific resource implementation.

    Author:
    Jordan Halterman

      • state

        Resource.State state()
        Returns the current resource state.

        The resource's Resource.State is indicative of the resource's ability to communicate with the cluster at any given time. Users of the resource should use the state to determine when guarantees may be lost. See the Resource.State documentation for information on the specific states, and see resource implementation documentation for the implications of different states on resource consistency.

        Returns:
        The current resource state.

      • onStateChange

        Listener<Resource.State> onStateChange(Consumer<Resource.State> callback)
        Registers a resource state change listener.
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to call when the resource state changes.
        Returns:
        The state change listener.

        Returns the resource thread context.
        Returns:

      • writeConsistency

        WriteConsistency writeConsistency()
        Returns the configured write consistency level.

        Resource consistency levels are configured via the with(WriteConsistency) setter. By default, all resources submit commands under the WriteConsistency.ATOMIC consistency level. See the WriteConsistency documentation for information about guarantees provided by specific consistency levels.

        Returns:
        The configured resource consistency level.

      • with

        T with(WriteConsistency consistency)
        Sets the write consistency level.

        The configured consistency level specifies how operations on the resource should be handled by the cluster. Consistency levels dictate the order in which reads, writes, and events should be handled by the Atomix cluster and the consistency requirements for completing different types of operations.

        Note that consistency configurations apply only to a single instance of a distributed resource. Two instances of the same resource on the same or different nodes can have different consistency requirements, and the cluster will obey those differences.

        By default, all resource operations are submitted to the cluster with the WriteConsistency.ATOMIC consistency level. Atomic consistency means that the distributed resource will behave as a single object for all instances. Users can decrease the default consistency level, but note that in some cases resource implementations may override the configured WriteConsistency for safety. For instance, a leader election may enforce atomic consistency at all times to ensure no two leaders can be elected at the same time.

        Parameters:
        consistency - The write consistency level.
        Returns:
        The resource instance.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if consistency is null

      • readConsistency

        ReadConsistency readConsistency()
        Returns the configured read consistency level.

        Resource consistency levels are configured via the with(ReadConsistency) setter. By default, all resources submit commands under the ReadConsistency.ATOMIC consistency level. See the ReadConsistency documentation for information about guarantees provided by specific consistency levels.

        Returns:
        The configured resource consistency level.

      • with

        T with(ReadConsistency consistency)
        Sets the read consistency level.

        The configured consistency level specifies how operations on the resource should be handled by the cluster. Consistency levels dictate the order in which reads, writes, and events should be handled by the Atomix cluster and the consistency requirements for completing different types of operations.

        Throws:

      • open

        CompletableFuture<T> open()
        Opens the resource.

        Once the resource is opened, the resource will be transitioned to the Resource.State.CONNECTED state and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Managed<T extends Resource<T>>
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the resource is opened.

      • close

        CompletableFuture<Void> close()
        Closes the resource.

        Once the resource is closed, the resource will be transitioned to the Resource.State.CLOSED state and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed. Thereafter, attempts to operate on the resource will fail.

        Specified by:
        close in interface Managed<T extends Resource<T>>
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the resource is closed.

      • delete

        CompletableFuture<Void> delete()
        Deletes the resource state.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the resource has been deleted.
